content: First, many users write in text-only mode. They see email for communication, and since HTML is a markup language, you can never know how your message is received. And, all of what you want to do can be done in Thunderbird. Multiple fonts, different sizes, underlines, etc. But, since HTML is a markup language, it sometimes requires some tweaking. You can do some extra editing - and also see how the markup language is applied, by adding this addon - thunderbirdHTMLedit, from https://betterbird.eu/addons/index.html
creator: davidsk

content:

content:
bachhuber_hans said
Thunderbird asks for the passwords of the mail accounts each time you log in, even though the checkbox for using the password manager has been set.

First, check if passwords are managed by an external app that is part of some security software. If there are no such apps in use, try this:

Help/Troubleshooting Info, Profile Folder, Open Folder, close TB, rename or delete keys4.db, cert9.db and logins.json, then restart TB, enter the passwords, check the box to store them, and see if they are remembered at next restart.

"Empty versions of those files will be automatically created. Logins.json stores the passwords. The other two are used to store security exceptions. However, they should be considered a set, if you delete one you should delete all three."

http://kb.mozillazine.org/Password_not_remembered_-_Thunderbird
creator: sfhowes

content:
I'm not sure I understand your situation. Keeping a mail account that can no longer connect to the server merely for archiving purposes doesn't make much sense to me…

Are you aware you may store your mail in Local Folders and organise your mail there however you wish, independently of any account? And you may also let Thunderbird handle the archiving of your messages in a more automated way:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/archived-messages
creator: DavidGG

content: Profilinizde parolaların kaydedildiği bazı dosyalar hasar görmüş olabilir. Menü > Yardım > Sorun giderme bilgilerine tıklayın. Profil klasörü satırının yanındaki "Klasörü aç" düğmesine tıklayın. Şimdi Thunderbird'ü kapatın. Açılan klasördeki cert9.db, key4.db ve secmod.db dosyalarını silin (hangileri mevcutsa). Thunderbird'ü açtığınızda bu dosyalar otomatik olarak yeniden oluşturulacaktır.

content:
• In Settings > Privacy and Security

In Passwords section

  • Click on 'Saved Passwords'
  • Click on 'Show Passwords'

You should see : If POP account: Two lines one for incoming - mailbox://account.... and one for outgoing: smtp://account.... If Imap account: Two lines one for incoming - imap://account.... and one for outgoing: smtp://account....

If any account has been set up to use Authentication Method: Oauth2 then you should only see one line for the account: oauth://account......

Do you see all your accounts in the Saved Passwords ? If yes, please right click on the relevant incoming line and select 'Edit Password' completely clear contents and then carefully type the correct password. Repeat for the outgoing line. clickon 'Close'

OR do all appear except the one that keeps asking for password ?
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
TB often defines what a 'junk' message is by a mark on the incoming email put there by the server through which it comes. So, that's a possibility...

...however, you didn't mention a filter. Have you set up a filter for that particular email address?

A filter can be set up by accessing the filter interface at Hamburger (top right)/Tools/Message Filters. See https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/organize-your-messages-using-filters

content: This happens because Thunderbird must be told where the profile is; it doesn't 'look' for it. Thunderbird opens this file: c:\users\<your id>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles.ini to get the name and location of the profile. You can edit that yourself with Notepad, or you can, from desktop, do this: - click windows key and 'r' key - enter thunderbird.exe -p and press enter - this is the profile manager. click the 'create profile' button and follow the steps to locate your profile, give a shortcut name, then click 'choose' and then finish and launch

content:
Here is the link for moving a profile in Windows when installed in default location: 

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there

I suggest you compare these steps to how you did the transfer, as that may open some ideas.
creator: davidsk

content: Well, you've "solved" the problem that way for the same reason it worked with POP, i.e. because you're storing your sent mail locally on your computer now, not on the server. Is that what you want? Because if not and you want your sent mail to be stored on the server, so you may also see it from e.g. webmail, then your problem is not solved…
creator: DavidGG

content:
rattana-ngam said
I changed the folder to the local folder. now it works :-).

As per DavidGG's post. This is more a masking of the problem rather than a resolution. With an IMAP account, you really want the sent items to be in your Sent Folder online so that it is mirrored in the IMAP Account section of Thunderbird - not in a local folder.
creator: frisée

creator: frisée

content:
Okay, this may sound strange, but here is the real way to set fonts on Thunderbird. And I attached examples of my own setting of Calibri 14 as my default. Follow this carefully and all of your messages will be consistent. In fact, with these settings, the majority of your messages will be sent as plain text, even though they may appear otherwise to you. Here goes:

  1. in Tools>settings>general, set your default font.
  2. then click the advanced button. Notice the drop-down menu at top. It probably says 'latin' or 'other writing systems' - this is IMPORTANT:
  3. select 'latin from that menu, set your desired font and font size settings, click OK,
  4. select 'otherwritingsystems' from the drop-down menu and set the IDENTICAL settings to what you did for Latin, and then click OK. In attached screenshots you will see my latin and otherwritingsystem match. Notice I also set monospace font.
  5. if you have account set to compose HTML, then set that in tools>settings>composition to variable-width and medium font. (You would only change the HTML font setting if your intent is for recipient to receive your preferred font - not my personal recommendation.)
  6. In settings>composition, set Sending Format to 'automatic' (just my preference, not required)

NOTE: if font size is still too small, try a larger number, such as 20. the numbers in thunderbird are points, not pixels.
creator: davidsk

content:
Thanks for your elaborate response. I can see this being helpful in some regards, but it doesn't really hit the point of what I'm going for.

In MS Word, there are styles that can be modified and locked in place to ensure that everything goes out consistently. The message window for TB has a dropdown with style names that can be chosen from, which I would expect to function in the same way. What I want to know is, where can I go to change those styles to be a font and size that I want it to be. If I want Heading 1 to be 4pt Arial and Address to be Comic Sans 36pt, where do I set that?
creator: lowraxe

content: Ok, you are obviously wanting to send HTML to recipients and expect recipients to read in HTML. You can see it while composing when selecting other styles, but that's manually done each time. I think you will do best by creating templates. Thunderbird's terminology generally follows normal expectations; for example, header one generates the H1 tag, header two generates the h2 tag, etc. How that appears to recipients depends on how their email client represents it. If a user just wants a special sig, that is readily done with HTML in the account pane - but requires the user to know sufficient HTML to do that. Changing H1 to 4pt Arial would require a special style sheet, so a template would be the only approach that I can see.
creator: davidsk

content:
That makes sense, but what I want to know is, where is that style sheet? Obviously those styles are being set somewhere. Where are they, so that I can change them to what I want?

BTW, I don't actually want to set anything to comic sans. I was just using that as an example.
creator: lowraxe

content: The style sheet is one that you must create in the template. When header one is selected, thunderbird uses the h1 tag, but does not specify anything specific, as there are general defaults, such as shown here: https://www.w3schools.com/cssref/css_default_values.php
creator: davidsk

content:
Filters are generally set up to run in the background, to save the user from some mundane tasks that aren't part of the default TB set up.

I would firstly check the parameters of the filters set up to make sure that they relate to the correct account and that 'run now' has something to filter.

creator: kmpaquette25

content:
Thunderbird thinking Inbox is a drafts folder… So funny… xD

So I figured there had to be a way to fix this without having to install the add-on, and there is. I installed the add-on to set the flag instead of to remove it, then did successfully remove the flag without using the add-on doing this:

  1. Open the account Copies & Folders settings.
  2. Under Drafts and Templates, choose Other, then select the account Inbox. You have to select the folder that has the problem here, not some other folder.
  3. Close the account settings (not sure this is necessary).
  4. Open Copies & Folders again and change the Drafts folder setting back to what it was. This is where having selected the right folder before matters, because it's when the folder that had been chosen to store drafts stops having that role that the flag is removed.

HTH… And looking forward to see more funny stories like this… :)
creator: DavidGG
